greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = 4*mu(n) + 5, where mu is the Moebius function (A008683).
comment: If n is prime (A000040), then a(n) = 1. The converse is not true: when n is the product of an odd number of distinct primes, mu(n) = -1 => a(n) = 1 (30 = 2*3*5, so a(30) = 1).

If n is semiprime (A001358), a(n) gives the number of divisors of n^2. In particular, if n = p^2 then n^2 = (p^2)^2 = p^4 has 5 divisors: p^4, p^3, p^2, p, 1. If n = pq (p,q distinct primes) then n^2 = (pq)^2 has 9 divisors: (pq)^2, qp^2, pq^2, p^2, q^2, pq, p, q, and 1.
a(n) = 1 if and only if n has an odd number of distinct prime factors, A030059. - _Jon Perry_, Nov 12 2013.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
results.author: _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Nov 09 2013
